div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7337] ALEXANDRIA, SATRUDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p: This Company's system of submarine telegraph cables is the most direct and quickest means of communication from Egypt to Europe, North and South America, East, South and West Africa, India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.
For latest average time to London, see daily bulletin in this paper.
STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo, Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Head Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Orient-Pacific Line of Royal Mail Steamers.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES FROM MAY TO OCTOBER INCLUSIVE.
OUTWARDS to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Orotava" will leave Suez about July 28 | R.M.S "Ormuz" will leave Suez about August 11.
HOMEWARDS to NAPLES MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY
R.M.S. "Oroya" will leave Port Said about July 18 | R.M.S. “Ortona" will leave Port Said about August 1
Egyptian Government Officials allowed a rebate of 15% off the above fares.

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of 1/3 fare back if return voyage be within 4 months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within 8 months of arrival.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all information apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT-SAID & PORT-TEWFIK (Suez) 31-12-904

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL STEAMERS.
div.p: Special Reduced Rates During Summer Season,
OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON. Departures from Suez.
S.S. Derbyshire 6,635 tons, leaves about July 20.
S.S. Lancashire 4,244 tons, leaves about August 3.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Worcestershire 7,160 tons, leaves about July 26.
S.S. Yorkshire 4,196 tons leaves about August 9,
FARES from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0, London £17.0.0, Colombo £32.10.0, Rangoon £37.10.0.
Agents Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS, 31-12-905

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS
GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

div.head: PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.
div.p: Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

div.head: RED SEA LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency. 31-12-904

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents. 26-12-905

div.head: P. HENDERSON & CO’s LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave SUEZ and PORT SAID fortnightly for LONDON or LIVERPOOL direct.
(Electric Light.) SALOON (Amidships) FARE £12. (Latest improvements.)
S.S. RANGOON 6000 Tons will leave PORT SAID about July 23 for London.
S.S. BURMA 5600 Tons will leave PORT SAID about August 6 for London.
S.S. ARRACAN 5800 Tons will leave PORT SAID about 20 for Liverpool
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL 12 days thereafter.

GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country! 10 12-904

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Naples, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday noon connecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste

(Departures from Suez) To Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama, Kobé about July 5 and August 4. To Aden, Karachi, and Bombay accelerated service about August 18. To Aden, Karachi, Bombay, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about July 20.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

MANUFACTURERS OF THE LARGEST AND MOST EFFICIENT Centrifugal Pumping Machinery In the world, suitable fcr all purposes, including RECLAMATION, DRAINAGE, IRRIGATION, SEWAGE WORKS, GRAVING & FLOATING DOCKS, MINES, & ALL MANUFACTURING PURPOSES.
These Pumps can be driven by Steam, Gas, Oil, Water, Electricity, or other power, for Lifts of from 1 ft. to 500ft., and from 5 to 500,000 Gallons a Minute. Makers of the Mex Pumps.
Results Guaranteed.
Over 50 Years' Practical Experience.
All kinds of Pumping and Irrigation Machinery specially designed to meet Egyptian requirements.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

row.cell: The cold at the end of the night is injurious.
Slowing of wheat (Lower Egypt.) Sow Lentils, chickpeas, and lupins. Apearance of first roses.
General tillage in Syria Animals grow lean.
Planting violets. Good season for preserving fruit.
Fresh winds. Begin to sow beans.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: The weather yesterday was again fine and clear. The morning opens with a light breeze from the N.E. and a steady barometer, but a somewhat cloudy sky.

div.head: RUSSIA’S PLIGHT. HORRORS FORESHADOWED. ARMED RISING PROBABLE. DEFECTION IN ARMY.
div.p: There is no improvement to record in the terrible condition of Russia. The revolutionary leaders foreshadow horrors eclipsing any yet recorded. They have ordered the suspension of the general strike for a period of 30 days, and are employing the interval in making the final preparations for an armed rising, unless complete satisfaction is given to the national demands.
There are symptoms of defection in the army, and that the troops are prepared to use their arms on the popular side.

Reports from the provinces show that there is nothing but turmoil and bloodshed, there being frequent slaughters of Jews. Martial law has been proclaimed at Odessa, and the Press censorship has been withdrawn.
The troops are re-assuming control of the city and clearing off the mobs. (Reuter)
The railway men are continuing the strike in order to prevent the despatch of troops to Finland. (Reuter)
An Imperial ukase proclaiming an amnesty was signed to-day at Peterhof.

The general situation throughout Russia is unchanged. Anti-Jewish disturbances and massacres continue at Kishineff, Rostoff, Kieff, Poltava, Sevastopol, and elsewhere. Communications by wireless telegraph have been established between the Prussian port Memel and Peterhoff, by means of a German cruiser and torpedo-boats. (Reuter)
The Tsar has signed an amnesty. (Havas)

div.head: THE ROYAL TOUR. ARRIVAL AT ADEN.
div.p: The Renown and Terrible passed here at midnight. (Reuter)
The Prince and Princess of Wales have arrived. The Fox and Proserpine have returned and will proceed to Bombay in company with the Renown. (Reuter)

div.head: CRETE. ACTION BY CONSULS.
div.p: The Consuls, on behalf of their Governments, have summoned the revolutionary chiefs to lay down arms, promising them a general amnesty and the assembly of a commission of enquiry to examine the necessity of reforms. (Reuter)

div.head: COTTON CONFERENCE.
div.p: The President of the Southern United States Cotton Association announces a conference, the date of which is not yet fixed, of representatives of Manchester, Continental, and American spinners, to establish doner relations, and stable prices. (Reuter)

div.head: MADAGASCAR. NEW GOVERNOR GENERAL.
div.p: The appointment of the deputy M. Augagneur as Governor-General of Madagascar has been signed. (Reuter)
M. Augagneur has been appointed Governor-General of Madagascar. (Havas)

div.head: NORWAY. FIRST BRITISH MINISTER.
div.p: Mr. Arthur James Herbert, Charge d’Af faires at Darmstadt, has been appointed first British Minister to Norway. (Reuter)

div.head: SIR CLAUDE MACDONALD.
div.p: Sir Claude Macdonald. K.C.B., has been promoted ambassador. (Reuter)

div.head: FRENCH CHAMBER.
div.p: The Chamber of Deputies passed simply the order of the day in the debate on an interpellation concerning the Lonywy strikes. (Havas)

div.head: UNIVERSAL SUFFRAGE.
div.p: Demonstrations in favor of universal suffrage have taken place at Prague and Grata. (H.)
The Legislative Council will meet on December 1 next

div.head: All Saints’, Cairo
div.p: The Rev. Professor Sayce will preach at All Saints’ Church, Cairo, on Sunday, 12th inst., and not to-morrow.
During the month of October 312 vessels passed through the Canal, the does from which amounted to frs. 8,903,400 31.

div.head: Reunion des Familles
div.p: This excellent Alexandrian society has organised a series of balls during the winter season at the New Khedivial Hotel.

div.head: The Anglo-Egyptian Land Allotment Co.
div.p: has opened a temporary office next door to Messrs. Rosseli and Kerr in Maison Chawarbi Pasha, Kasr el-Nil-atrest, Cairo.

div.head: Irrigation Department
div.p: Abdel Latif Bey el Moweilihi, son of Abdel Salam Pasha, has been appointed chief engineer of the teftish in charge of the Second Circle of Irrigation in the Gharbieh Province.

div.head: Murder at Cairo
div.p: A quarrel took place on Thursday between two natives of the Sayeda Zenab quarter of Cairo, and one of them became so excited that he thrust a knife into the other’s heart, killing him on the spot. The murderer was arrested.

div.head: Our Commercial Review
div.p: From to-day we will publish a special early edition of our Commercial Review in order that it may be despatched to Europe every Saturday afternoon by the Austrian Lloyd mail. The subscription to this review is P.T. 50 per aunum.

div.head: Coal Imports
div.p: During the period from 1st January to 2nd November, 919,9 96 tons of coal were imported into Egypt. Wales sent 495,416, Newcastle 214,545, Scotland 1[]0,924, Yorkshire 64,303 and other places 34,708 tons. Daring the same period last year 889,464 tons were received.

div.head: Alexandria Pickpocket Case
div.p: Yesterday a European lady was passing near Santi’s Restaurant at Alexandria when a pickpocket seized her purse and made off The lady, who declared that the purse contained £50, fainted. The thief, though hotly pursued, made good his escape.

div.head: A Record
div.p: An American importer at Alexandria has received a quantity of goods from New York within fourteen days. The goods were transhipped to the S 3. Schleswig at Naples. Fourteen days from New York to Alexandria is a record, the average time for mails being sixteen days.

div.head: The Union Artistique Francaise
div.p: give their eighth performance at the Eden Theatre to-night, when a triple programme will be presented, viz., Francois Coppee’s 1-act comedy Le Luthier de Cremone, the drama La Dernire Idole, and the comedy Un jeune Homme presse. The curtain will rise at 9 p.m.

div.head: Alhambra Theatre
div.p: The Gardet French comedy company is meeting with great success at the Alhambra. This evening the company will present Le Sursis, a military vaudeville in 3 acts. This will be preceded by an operetta entitled Les Charbonniers. To-morrow a matinee performance will be given of La Cagnotte, the legendary vaudeville from the Palais Royal. In the evening, one of the Palais Royal’s greatest successes, Cheri, will be produced.

div.head: ARRIVALS.
div.p: Le paquebot “Moulouya” des Messageries Maritimes arrivé de Marseille le 4 Novembre avait à bord :

M. Kress et ami, M. Marietti, Mlle Floridal, Mlle Mariette, Mlle Beau regard, M. Viannay, M. Leboox et 3 enfants, M. Bernard, Mlle Bougier, Mlle V. Zahar, Mlle Hoohstrasse, Mme Petit, M. Âlessandri, M. Délavai, M. Belonole.

div.head: DEPARTURES.
div.p: Le paquebot “Senegal” des Messageries Maritimes parti poor Marseille le 3 Novembre avait k bord:

M. et Mme Ronillot, M. Ibrahim Fehime M. Dibbina, M. et Mme Leoerf, M. Ballatiano, M. A. Buoau, M. et Mme Poutrel et fils, M. Combe, M. Rioha, Mile Miranda, Frdre Xenophon et 47 passagers de Sme olasse.

div.head: COTTON IN KOREA. EXTENSIVE CULTIVATION
div.p: We understand that, though nothing has been definitely settled, the new lunatic asylum will probably not be constructed near the desert edge west of Damanhour, in the Behera Province, as was previously expected. The Behera site had certain disadvantages, chief among them the absence of stone quarries which would have greatly increased the cost of construction,a brick building costing at least twice as much as one constructed of local building stone, many good varieties of which are available and abundant, especially near the edge of the Eastern (Arabian) desert.

The choice of a site at Khanka, a lew miles beyond Khanka, is now being discussed, and we understand that Sir Horace Pinching Pasha, Dr. Warnock, and Mr. Courtenay Clifton, the first two representing the Sanitary Department and the latter the Ministry of Public Works, will proceed next week to the spot from Marg and examine the proposed site. The new asylum will probably be built in the hard desert fairly near Khanka—if built in the neighbourhood of Cairo at all—where there are water wells which yield a good supply, and abundance of building stone is within easy reach. The climate of Khanka is good, and the town, which was at one time a fairly important centre, but is said to have been declining recently, may well benefit by the construction of‘the asylum, especially if the Marg-Matarieh railway, as was formerly proposed, is prolonged from Marg to Khanka. The embankments for part at least of the intervening distance were laid down and rails and embankment alike reach Alag some two miles N. E. of Marg and a little less than one-third of the way to Khanka.
Sir Peroy Girouard, it will be remembered, at one time contemplated the extension of the Cairo-Marg line through Khanka to the well-known Abou-Zaabel stone quarries.

div.head: NEW LUNATIC ASYLUM.
div.p: The fine new hotel in the Sharia Soliman Pasha, one of the largest and most up-to-date in Cairo, will be formally inaugurated on Thursday next, when a concert, and later a ball, will be given.

The building, which can accommodate 200 guests, has been furnished throughout by Messrs. S. Davis and Sons, of London. It is lighted throughout by electricity and possesses lifts and all the very latest sanitary improvements. There are also a restaurant and grill room, bar and billiard-rooms, eta The whole of the rooms have already been retained for the middle of next month.

div.head: NATIONAL HOTEL
div.p: The Japanese Government is taking active steps to secure cotton culture on a large scale in Korea. Experiments which have been made have proved that the soil is suitable for its cultivation.

div.head: HELOUAN.
div.p: The season at Helouan is beginning under the best auspices. There are already many visitors at the different hotels, and the Grand Hotel, which opened its doors on the 1st inst, has began with a goodly number of guests. We notice among them Mr. and Mrs. von Wedderkop, Mrs. P. Koop, Miss Koop, Mr. S. Manuel, Dr. O. Hobson, Messrs. J. H. and S. R Charles worth, Mr. P. S. Barlow, Mr. John L. Oliver, and Mr. Geo. Patterson.

div.head: BUILDING SITES AND SANITATION.
div.p: Our attention has been called by some of our readers to one of the most unpleasant accompaniments of building activity at Cairo.

To put the matter plainly, in far too many cases, no conveniences of any sort are supplied for the use of the workmen, with the result that an amount of filth is allowed to be spread broadcast in the neighbourhood of these buildings, which is bound to have a prejudicial effect on the health or at least on the comfort of the neighbourhood Dead dogs and cats and other offal are frequently thrown into these sites and may remain there for two or three days, festering and horrible, to the disgust of passers-by. Would it be impossible for the Sanitary Department to force contractors to provide latrines, eta, for the use of the workmen, which could be cleared out from time to time by carts? A rule of this sort has long been applied to all such cases in the British Islands, and has proved a decided success from the point of view of the comfort and health of all concerned.

div.head: NILE TOURISTS.
div.p: The following passengers left Cairo for the Nile trip yesterday by the P. S. Hataaoo Mrs. H. Halsey Vail, Miss M. Vail, Mr. H.H. Worthington, Mr. Rollo Worthington, Mrs. Worthington, Miss Knight, Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Watson, Mr. and Mrs. W. Brand, Miss Brand, Mrs. Stevens,

div.head: DEATH OF GRAND MUFTI. APPOINTED TWO DAYS AGO.
div.p: The new Grand Mufti of Egypt, Sheikh Abdel Kader El Rafei, died in Cairo at 8 o’clock yesterday evening, it is believed, from heart failure.

The deceased, who was appointed only two days ago to the Grand Muftiship, in place of the late Sheikh Mohamed Abdou, was of the Hanafi sect and enjoyed a great reputation for piety and learning. His death is greatly deplored among Moslem circles, which had been greatly pleased by his recent appointment

The statement of one of our contemporaries, that the late Grand Mufti was found dead in his carriage on returning from a visit to the British Agency, is not correct Sheikh El Rafei’s last visit to the British Agency took place two days ago, immediately after his nomination.
It is of course too early for discussion as to who will succeed him in the Grand Muftiship.

div.head: WEDDING AT ST. MARK’S.
div.p: A marriage took place on the 1st inst. at St Mark’s Church, Alexandria, between Mr. Denys Goldney Birch and Miss Lucy H. B. Burton. Canon Ward and the Rev. R. Wormell officiated. The bride wore a pretty dress of white crepe de Chine trimmed with Bruges lace and orange blossom, and a tulle veil with sprays of same. Her cousin, Miss Sepsi, attended her as bridesmaid. She wore a white silk dress, white hat and pink roses. The bride was given away by her uncle, Mr. Sepsi, and Mr. Hirsch acted as “best man.” Numerous relatives and friends ware present at the church, many of whom went on afterwards to Mr. and Mrs. L. H. Birch's house at Ramleh to wish good luck to, and drink the health of, the newly-married couple. The presents were numerous, among them

being ;—bride to bridegroom, antique silver electric lamp-candle sticks and accessories for writing table; bridegroom to bride, red Morocco leather silver dressing case, gold watch and chain; Mr. and Mrs. L. H. Birch, oheque; Mr. and Mrs. A. H. Payton, furniture; Mr. and Mrs. A. Sepsi, silver tray with and and tea service ; Mr. I. Sepsi, two crystal and silver decanters, with cake dish ; Miss S. Sepsi, silver card tray ; Mrs. M. Biroh, oheque; Mr. C. H. Biroh, Gladstone bag; Mr. L. G. Biroh, brass bowl; Mr. and Mrs. C. J. Choremi, gold soent bottle set with ruby and brilliants; Mr. W. F. Peel, 2 silver vases ;Mrs..Braddyil, oheque; Mr.A.F. Hirsoh, silver rose bowl; Mr. and Mrs K. P. Birley, silver pepper pots. Handsome presents were also reoeived from Mr. R Gteutilii, Mr. H. Heraolt, Mia Buffer, Mr. and Mrs. R G. C. Moss,' Mr. a R C. Moss, Mr., Mrs. and Miss Bell, Mr. R. Remanda, Mr. A. Remanda, Mr. and Mrs. G. A. Williams, Mr. D. Anastasiadis, Mr. M. A. Caloyanni, Mr. L. Vivante, Mr. 8. Emmens, Miss Demech, Miss A Demeoh, Mr. a Blattner, Mr. R.Blattner, Mrs.VveF.Giglio, Mr. 0. Barany, Mr. A. H. Mieli, Mr. Pandelidis, Mrs. Terlendi, Mr. F. Leveaux, Mr. C. Peel, Mr. W. A Biroh, Mr. Oswald Gorra, Mr. A. M. Giglio, Mr. Pegna, Mr. A. Bassiliadis, Mr. and Mrs. Kelham, Miss L. J. Peel, Mr. and Mrs. L. J.Peel, etc., eto.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: H.H. Prince Leopold of Battenburg who is leaving Marseilles for Port Said on the 24th instant by the orient-pacific steamer Ormuz, will stay a week in Cairo before proceeding to Assouan. A suite of apartments has been retained for his Highness at the Hotel d’Angleterre.
Immediately on his arrival at Constantinople the Grand Cadi of Egypt was summoned to a private audience with the Sultan.
Adly Pasha Yaghen, Governor of Cairo, will probably arrive from Europe on Monday next, and will resume his functions on the following day.
Mat. fi M Pasha is expected to return from leave next Monday
Judge H. W. Halton is returning by the P. & 0. steamer Mooltan, due at Port Said on the 14th November.
Col. Aylmer has returned to Cairo from England.
Mr. Howard Carter has resigned his inspectorship under the Antiquities Service.
Dr. Murison has returned to Cairo from England.

The many friends of Dr. Hayes, who was compelled to leave Egypt several months ago on account of serious illness, will be pleased to hear that he is completely restored to health, and will soon be returning from England to resume his duties at the Quarantine office in Suez.

div.head: THE NAZLEH WATERFALL.
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior and the Public Works Department have granted a concession for working the Nazleh waterfall to the Mixed Tribunal of Fayoum, in order that it may be used for the benefit of the inhabitants of Medinet el-Fayoum. There are, however, no public funds available for the purpose, and it is proposed to offer the concession to capitalists, who, after supplying the necessary power for Lighting Fayoum by electricity, could apply, the surplus to commercial purposes.

div.head: IRRIGATION DEPARTMENT.
div.p: Mr. Clowes left Fayoum yesterday for Wasta. Mr. Ireland is in Beni Souef province. Mr. Box is expected to leave Fayoum shortly, much to the regret of the fellaheen, who have always found him mindful of their just rights in the matter of water supply.

div.head: MINISTRY OF THE INTERIOR.
div.p: Major Elgood arrived yesterday, but without an assistant, his late assistant having been appointed secretary to the Adviser. Major Elgood’s district now comprises the provinces of Fayoum, Beni Souef, and Ghiseh, known sometimes as Middle Egypt. The Major knows the Fayoum well, and frequently is called upon to settle disputes between village sheikhs.

div.head: NATIVE TRIBUNAL.
div.p: Boutros Girgis, a clerk in Beni Souef Tribunal, who is charged with disposing of official documents, some of which he is said to have sold to Madame Astireh, is to be tried by the Native Court on the 7th inst. Much public interest is manifested in the case.

div.head: CRICKET.
EAST INDIES SQUADRON v. E.T.C.
(SUEZ).
div.p: A match was played at Suez between the above teams on Thursday, 26th ulto., resulting in a somewhat easy win for the E.T.C. Meet. The E.T.C. batted first, but were soon out for the small score of 55, thanks to the bowling of Mansell and some excellent fielding by the members of the E.T.C. Lt. Wolfe-Murray, the captain, was the only one to reach double figures, playing a steady innings. The E/T.C. found no difficulty in knocking off the required number owing to the batting of Mansell and Toms, and were able to declare at 109 for 5. The Squadron, going in a second time, ran up a total of 72 for 5, a very pleasant game thus being won by the RT.C. on the first innings by 54 runs.,Scores

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Roman Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Manchester on Friday and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about November 19 via Tunis and Malta.

div.head: BANK OF ABYSSINIA.
div.p: Constituted with limited LUbfitty wafer Khedivial Decree dated 80th of May 1905.

div.head: Board of Directors.
div.p: President: The Governor of the National Bank of Egypt
Vice-President : The Governor of the Bank of Abyssinia.
S.E Boghos Pasha Nubar, Director of the National Bank of Egypt.
Baron J. De Menaace, Director of the National Bank of Egypt
Raphael Suares, Director of the National Bank of Egypt
H.H. Ras Makunan, Governor of Harrar and its dependencies.
H.H. Has Walda Giorgis, Governor of Kaffa and its dependencies.
F. Monvoirin, director of the Societe Generale de Credit Industrial et Commercial, Paris. .
M. le Commr. Francesco Varvaro Projero, Director tor of the Banca d’ltalia, Rome.
Wilhelm Pelizaeus, Cairo.
The Head Office of the Bank of Abyssinia will be at Adis Ababs
The Registered Offices of the Bank will be at Cairo.

The National Bank of Bgypt having obtained a Concession from H. M. The Emperor Menelak for the constitution of a Company with liability limited to the nominal amount of the Shares under the name of the Bank of Abyssinia, and the said Bank having been founded under Egyptian Law and authorised by Khedivial Decree on the 80th May, 1905, the National Bank of Egypt offer for sale, on account of themselves and other parties entitled, the above mentioned 100,000 shares (£1. 5s. paid) at the price of £7 per Share (of which £2 is premium and £t.5s. already paid up on the shares) payable to the vendors as follows
£9. 10s. Od. on Application,
15s. Od. on Allotment.
The Balance of £8 15s. Od. per Share, making them fully paid, will be payable to the Bank of Abyssinia as required by it, an, interval of at least two months elapsing between the calls.
The Lists will open on the 7th November, 1905, and will close the same day.
Applications will be received:—
In Adis-Abaha.
In Cairo and Alexandria, at the National Bank of Egypt-
In London, at the Agency of the National Bank of Egypt, 4 & 5, King william Street In Paris, at the Societe Generale de Credit Industrial et Commercial, 66, Rue de la Victoire.
In Rome, Genoa and Milan, at the Banoa d’ltalia, at la Banca Commerciale Italiana, at the Credito Italiano, and at the Societe Bancaria Italiana & Banca di Roma.
In Berlin, at the Bank fur Handel & Industrie.
In Vienna, at the Creditanstalt fur Handel and Gewerbe.
In New York, at Messrs. Baring, Magonn & Co.
The Warrants will be to Beaver, and will be issued as £1 5s. paid.
Dividend payments will be effected at the Companies Offices, the National Bank of Egypt, and at the other establishments above mentioned. ____________________
The work of economic progress for Abyssinia, to collaborate in which this Bank is formed, and by which it should benefit, is one requiring time for development.
In accordance with the Statutes, the object of the Bank of Abyssinia is to carry on all Banking, commensal, financial and industrials operations, especially in Abyssinia.

The following eight privileges are,granted exclusively to the Bank of Abyssinia, beginning on the day on which it is constituted and lasting daring the 50 years forming the term of the Concession and of the Statutes -
1. The Emperor will not allow any other Bank to be established in his Kingdom.

2. the Bank of Abyssinia will have the sole right to issue Bank notes. The notes of the Bank of Abyssinia shall be legal tender in Abyssinia and will be exchanged for the beam in gold or silver at the Head Office of the Bank of Abyssinia.
3. The Government will not mint any coin. All minting will he done in consultation with the Government by the Bank of Abyssinia, who have the profit resulting therefrom.
4. All the Government public funds shall be deposited with the Bank of Abyssinia and Government payments shall be made by cheques drawn on the Bank.
5. Preference will be given to the Bank of Abyssinia tor all issues of Government loans.
6. The Bank of Abyssinia is given permission to build warehouses, wherein merchants may deposit their goods against loans from the Bank.
7. The Government of Abyssinia will give a free grant to the Bank of Abyssinia of all the lands necessary for the establishment of the Head Office, its Agencies and warehouses.
8. The Bank of Abyssinia shall have transport for its specie by rail in Abyssinia at Government rates.
With regard to the division of profits, Article 89 of the Statutes determines that the net proceeds will, after deduction of all charges, constitute the profits, which will be divisible as follows: —
1. Ten per cent, is to be set aside to form the ordinary Reserve Fund.
2. A sum shall next be set aside sufficient to pay to the Shareholders seven per cent interest on the Amount paid upon the Shares.
3. After then deductions the remaining profits shall be divided in the following manner)
As to twenty per cent. to the National Bank of Egypt, to be applied in conformity with the Act of Concession.
As to the remaining eighty per cent to the Shareholders.

Copies of the Concession, of the Khedivial Decree, end of the Statutes site be seen by intending Subscribers at tha Offices of the London Agency of the National Bank of Egypt, 4 and 5. King William Street London, K.C.
Prospectuses and Application Forms can be obtained at the offices of the national Bank of Egypt, 4 & 5, King Willima Street, Lonthon, E.C. 26 October 1906
